title: The Song of Deborah
shortSummary: Judges chapter 5 presents the poetic Song of Deborah, celebrating God's deliverance of Israel through the leadership of Deborah and Barak. This victory song recounts the battle against the Canaanite general Sisera, highlighting God's power and the faithfulness of His people. It emphasizes the importance of obedience, courage, and divine intervention in Israel's history.
timeline: c. 1200 BC - Period of the Judges, shortly after the Exodus and conquest of Canaan

keyCharacters.name: Deborah
keyCharacters.description: A prophetess and judge of Israel who leads the people spiritually and militarily, and co-authors the victory song.

keyCharacters.name: Barak
keyCharacters.description: Son of Abinoam, a military leader who obeys Deborah's call to lead Israel's army against Sisera.

keyCharacters.name: Jael
keyCharacters.description: The wife of Heber the Kenite who kills Sisera, the enemy commander, securing Israel’s victory.

keyCharacters.name: Sisera
keyCharacters.description: Commander of the Canaanite army defeated by Israel and killed by Jael.

definitions.definition: A mountainous region associated with Edom, symbolizing God's powerful presence as He leads Israel.
A minor judge mentioned here to set the historical context of Israel’s oppression before Deborah’s leadership.
Refers to the lively, spirited movements of horses, symbolizing the broken strength of Sisera’s chariots.
A nomadic tribe allied with Israel; Jael, a Kenite woman, plays a pivotal role in the defeat of Sisera.

outline.heading: Introduction and Call to Praise
outline.description: Deborah and Barak begin by praising the LORD for delivering Israel, recounting God’s mighty acts in nature and history as a foundation for the victory.

outline.heading: Israel’s Condition Before the Victory
outline.description: The song describes Israel’s oppression and spiritual decline before Deborah’s rise, highlighting the people's need for deliverance and leadership.

outline.heading: Call to Action and Tribal Participation
outline.description: Deborah calls Barak to lead, and the song praises the tribes that courageously joined the battle while rebuking those who stayed behind.

outline.heading: The Battle and Divine Intervention
outline.description: The song recounts the battle against Sisera, emphasizing God’s supernatural aid through the stars and the river Kishon, which overwhelmed the enemy.

outline.heading: Jael’s Heroic Deed
outline.description: Jael is blessed for her decisive act of killing Sisera, which secured Israel’s victory and brought peace.

outline.heading: Victory Celebrated and Israel’s Rest
outline.description: The song concludes with the lament of Sisera’s mother and a prayer for the destruction of Israel’s enemies and blessing for those who love the LORD.

application: Trust in God's sovereign power to deliver His people even in seemingly impossible situations.
Respond to God's call with courage and obedience, as Barak did under Deborah’s leadership.
Recognize the importance of faithful leadership and the role of godly women like Deborah and Jael in God's plan.
Commit to supporting fellow believers in spiritual battles rather than remaining passive or indifferent.

keyVerses.text: Praise ye the LORD for the avenging of Israel, when the people willingly offered themselves.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the importance of willing obedience and praise in God's deliverance.

keyVerses.text: They fought from heaven; the stars in their courses fought against Sisera.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes God's direct supernatural intervention in the victory over Israel's enemies.

keyVerses.text: Blessed above women shall Jael the wife of Heber the Kenite be, blessed shall she be above women in the tent.
keyVerses.significance: This verse honors Jael’s courageous act, showing God’s use of unexpected instruments to accomplish His purposes.

keyVerses.text: So let all thine enemies perish, O LORD: but let them that love him be as the sun when he goeth forth in his might. And the land had rest forty years.
keyVerses.significance: It concludes the chapter with a prayer for God's justice and a reminder of the peace that follows obedience and deliverance.
